head.title: Lyme Disease Declines; Drought Is Likely Reason

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New Jersey
Top/News/Health/Diseases, Conditions, and Health Topics/Lyme Disease

hedline.hl1: Lyme Disease Declines; Drought Is Likely Reason

abstract.p: Tom Forschner, executive director of Lyme Disease Foundation, reports cases of disease reported in New Jersey during 1999 dropped by nearly 50 percent, probably because summer drought killed many of deer ticks that carry disease; photo (S)

block.p: Cases of Lyme disease reported in New Jersey during 1999 dropped by nearly 50 percent, probably because the summer drought killed many of the deer ticks that carry the disease, according to Tom Forschner, executive director of the national Lyme Disease Foundation, based in Hartford, Conn.

From Jan. 1 through Dec. 12, 1998, 922 cases of Lyme disease were reported in New Jersey, compared with 1,802 cases during the same time period in 1998. The incidence of Lyme disease was down nationally but not as dramatically as in New Jersey. Nationally, 12,207 cases were reported by Dec. 12 in 1999 compared with 15,094 cases during the same time period the year before.

Cases of Lyme disease reported in New Jersey during 1999 dropped by nearly 50 percent, probably because the summer drought killed many of the deer ticks that carry the disease, according to Tom Forschner, executive director of the national Lyme Disease Foundation, based in Hartford, Conn.

From Jan. 1 through Dec. 12, 1998, 922 cases of Lyme disease were reported in New Jersey, compared with 1,802 cases during the same time period in 1998. The incidence of Lyme disease was down nationally but not as dramatically as in New Jersey. Nationally, 12,207 cases were reported by Dec. 12 in 1999 compared with 15,094 cases during the same time period the year before.
Mr. Forschner said that though the tick population dropped last year, they reproduce so quickly that they could be back in force by next summer.
New Jersey remains one of the three states with the highest rate of Lyme disease along with Connecticut and Rhode Island.
